stem: Complete the teaching for a client with Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG).
template: A client with POAG must continue therapeutic eye drops {{frequency}} to prevent {{complication}}.

options: for the rest of their life
only when they have eye pain
blanks.correctOption: for the rest of their life

options: permanent optic nerve damage and blindness
blanks.correctOption: permanent optic nerve damage and blindness

rationale.correct: Glaucoma is high intraocular pressure (IOP) that kills the optic nerve. (1) It is a chronic, progressive disease with no cure; drops must be lifelong. (2) Without treatment, peripheral vision loss becomes total, leading to permanent blindness.
rationale.incorrect: Most types of glaucoma are painless (the 'silent thief of sight'). Medication will not 'restore' lost vision; it only prevents further loss.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "for the rest of their life" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "permanent optic nerve damage and blindness" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

clinicalPearls: Instruct the client to avoid medications with anticholinergic side effects (e.g., Atropine, some antihistamines), which can dangerously increase IOP in certain types of glaucoma.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that *Open-angle* is PAINLESS. *Closed-angle* is the PAINFUL emergency.

reviewUnits.heading: Assessment and Care of the Visual System
reviewUnits.body: Nurses teach the proper technique for administering eye drops, including punctal occlusion to prevent systemic absorption.
